member.value: If not specified, a random unique identifier will be generated.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Primitives.PartitionReceiverOptions.OwnerLevel
member.summary:
When populated, the owner level indicates that a reading is intended to be performed exclusively for events in the requested partition and for the associated consumer group. To do so, reading will attempt to assert ownership over the partition; in the case where more than one exclusive reader attempts to assert ownership for the same partition/consumer group pair, the one having a larger value will "win."
When an exclusive reader is used, other readers which are non-exclusive or which have a lower owner level will either not be allowed to be created, if they already exist, will encounter an exception during the next attempted operation.
member.value: The relative priority to associate with an exclusive reader; for a non-exclusive reader, this value should be null. The default owner level is null.
member.exception: Occurs when the owner level is set and the is unable to read from the requested Event Hub partition due to being denied ownership. In this case, the will be set to .

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Primitives.PartitionReceiverOptions.PrefetchCount
member.summary: The number of events that will be eagerly requested from the Event Hubs service and queued locally without regard to whether a read operation is currently active, intended to help maximize throughput by allowing events to be read from from a local cache rather than waiting on a service request.
member.value:
The is a control that developers can use to help tune performance for the specific needs of an application, given its expected size of events, throughput needs, and expected scenarios for using Event Hubs.
The default prefetch count is 300.
member.exception: Occurs when the requested count is negative.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Primitives.PartitionReceiverOptions.PrefetchSizeInBytes
member.summary: The desired number of bytes to attempt to eagerly request from the Event Hubs service and queued locally without regard to whether a read operation is currently active, intended to help maximize throughput by allowing events to be read from from a local cache rather than waiting on a service request.

value.para: When set to null, the option is considered disabled; otherwise, it will be considered enabled and take precedence over any value specified for the The is an advanced control that developers can use to help tune performance in some scenarios; it is recommended to prefer using the over this option where possible for more accurate control and more predictable throughput.

This size should be considered a statement of intent rather than a guaranteed limit; the local cache may be larger or smaller than the number of bytes specified, and will always contain at least one event when the is specified. A heuristic is used to predict the average event size to use for size calculations, which should be expected to fluctuate as traffic passes through the system. Consequently, the resulting resource use will fluctuate as well.
This option is disabled by default with the value set to null.

member.exception: Occurs when the requested size is negative.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Primitives.PartitionReceiverOptions.TrackLastEnqueuedEventProperties
member.summary: Indicates whether or not the reader should request information on the last enqueued event on the partition associated with a given event, and track that information as events are read.
member.value: true if information about a partition's last event should be requested and tracked; otherwise, false. The default value is true.
member.remarks: When information about a partition's last enqueued event is being tracked, each event received from the Event Hubs service will carry metadata about the partition that it otherwise would not. This results in a small amount of additional network bandwidth consumption that is generally a favorable trade-off when considered against periodically making requests for partition properties using one of the Event Hub clients.

member.name: T:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Primitives.PluggableCheckpointStoreEventProcessor`1
member.summary: Provides a base for creating an event processor with custom processing logic which consumes events across all partitions of a given Event Hub for a specific consumer group. The processor is capable of collaborating with other instances for the same Event Hub and consumer group pairing to share work by using a common storage platform to communicate. Fault tolerance is also built-in, allowing the processor to be resilient in the face of errors.
member.typeparam: The context of the partition for which an operation is being performed.
member.remarks:
To enable coordination for sharing of partitions between instances, they will assert exclusive read access to partitions for the consumer group. No other readers should be active in the consumer group other than processors intending to collaborate. Non-exclusive readers will be denied access; exclusive readers, including processors using a different storage locations, will interfere with the processor's operation and performance.
The is safe to cache and use for the lifetime of an application, and that is best practice when the application processes events regularly or semi-regularly. The processor holds responsibility for efficient resource management, working to keep resource usage low during periods of inactivity and manage health during periods of higher use. Calling either the or method when processing is complete or as the application is shutting down will ensure that network resources and other unmanaged objects are properly cleaned up.

member.name: M:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Primitives.PluggableCheckpointStoreEventProcessor`1.#ctor(Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Primitives.CheckpointStore,System.Int32,System.String,System.String,Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Primitives.EventProcessorOptions)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Responsible for creation of checkpoints and for ownership claim. Processor instances sharing this storage will attempt to coordinate and share work.

The desired number of events to include in a batch to be processed. This size is the maximum count in a batch; the actual count may be smaller, depending on whether events are available in the Event Hub.
The name of the consumer group this processor is associated with. The processor will assert exclusive read access to partitions for this group.
The connection string to use for connecting to the Event Hubs namespace; it is expected that the Event Hub name and the shared key properties are contained in this connection string.
The set of options to use for the processor.
member.remarks:
If the connection string is copied from the Event Hubs namespace, it will likely not contain the name of the desired Event Hub, which is needed. In this case, the name can be added manually by adding ";EntityPath=[[ EVENT HUB NAME ]]" to the end of the connection string. For example, ";EntityPath=telemetry-hub".
If you have defined a shared access policy directly on the Event Hub itself, then copying the connection string from that Event Hub will result in a connection string that contains the name.
member.exception: Occurs when the requested is less than 1.
member.seealso: How to get an Event Hubs connection string

member.name: T:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Processor.LoadBalancingStrategy
member.summary: The strategy that an event processor will use to make decisions about partition ownership when performing load balancing to share work with other event processors.

member.name: F:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Processor.LoadBalancingStrategy.Balanced
member.summary:
An event processor will take a measured approach to requesting partition ownership when balancing work with other processors, slowly claiming partitions until a stabilized distribution is achieved.
When using this strategy, it may take longer for all partitions of an Event Hub to be owned by a processor when processing first starts, the number of active processors changes, or when partitions are scaled. The Balanced strategy will reduce contention for a partition, ensuring that once it is claimed, processing will be more likely to be steady and consistent.

member.name: F:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Processor.LoadBalancingStrategy.Greedy
member.summary:
An event processor will attempt to claim ownership of its fair share of partitions aggressively when balancing work with other processors.
When using this strategy, all partitions of an Event Hub will be claimed quickly when processing first starts, the number of active processors changes, or when partitions are scaled. The Greedy strategy is likely to cause competition for ownership of a given partition, causing it to see sporadic processing and some amount of duplicate events until balance has been reached and work is distributed equally among the active processors.

member.summary: Attempts to add an event to the batch, ensuring that the size of the batch does not exceed its maximum.
member.param: The event to attempt to add to the batch.
member.returns: true if the event was added; otherwise, false.
member.remarks:
When an event is accepted into the batch, changes made to its properties will not be reflected in the batch nor will any state transitions be reflected to the original instance.
Note: Any , byte array, or instance associated with the event is referenced by the batch and must remain valid and unchanged until the batch is disposed.
member.exception: When a batch is published, it will be locked for the duration of that operation. During this time, no events may be added to the batch. Calling TryAdd while the batch is being published will result in an until publishing has completed.
Occurs when the has a member in its collection that is an unsupported type for serialization. See the remarks for details.

member.name: T:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient
member.summary:
A client responsible for publishing instances of to a specific Event Hub. Depending on the options specified when events are enqueued, they may be automatically assigned to a partition, grouped according to the specified partition key, or assigned a specifically requested partition.
The does not publish immediately, instead using a deferred model where events are collected into a buffer so that they may be efficiently batched and published when the batch is full or the has elapsed with no new events enqueued.
This model is intended to shift the burden of batch management from callers, at the cost of non-deterministic timing, for when events will be published. There are additional trade-offs to consider, as well:
If the application crashes, events in the buffer will not have been published. To prevent data loss, callers are encouraged to track publishing progress using the and handlers.
Events specifying a partition key may be assigned a different partition than those using the same key with other producers.
In the unlikely event that a partition becomes temporarily unavailable, the may take longer to recover than other producers.
In scenarios where it is important to have events published immediately with a deterministic outcome, ensure that partition keys are assigned to a partition consistent with other publishers, or where maximizing availability is a requirement, using the is recommended.
member.remarks: The is safe to cache and use as a singleton for the lifetime of an application, which is the recommended approach. The producer is responsible for ensuring efficient network, CPU, and memory use. Calling either or when no more events will be enqueued or as the application is shutting down is required so that the buffer can be flushed and resources cleaned up properly.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient.FullyQualifiedNamespace
member.summary: The fully qualified Event Hubs namespace that this producer is currently associated with, which will likely be similar to {yournamespace}.servicebus.windows.net.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient.EventHubName
member.summary: The name of the Event Hub that this producer is connected to, specific to the Event Hubs namespace that contains it.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient.Identifier
member.summary: A unique name to identify the buffered producer.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient.IsPublishing
member.summary: Indicates whether or not this is currently active and publishing queued events.
member.value: true if the client is publishing; otherwise, false.
member.remarks:
The producer will begin publishing when an event is enqueued and should remain active until either or is called.
If any events were enqueued, is false, and is false, this likely indicates an unrecoverable state for the client. It is recommended to close the and create a new instance.
In this state, exceptions will be reported by the Event Hubs client library logs, which can be captured using the .
member.seealso: Capturing Event Hubs logs

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient.IsClosed

member.name: E:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient.SendEventBatchSucceededAsync
member.summary:
Invoked after each batch of events has been successfully published to the Event Hub, this handler is optional and is intended to provide notifications for interested listeners. If this producer was configured with or set greater than 1, the handler will be invoked concurrently.
This handler will be awaited after publishing the batch; the publishing operation will not be considered complete until the handler call returns. It is advised that no long-running operations be performed in the handler to avoid negatively impacting throughput.
It is not recommended to invoke or from this handler; doing so may result in a deadlock scenario if those calls are awaited.
member.remarks: It is not necessary to explicitly unregister this handler; it will be automatically unregistered when or is invoked.
member.exception: If an attempt is made to remove a handler that doesn't match the current handler registered.
If an attempt is made to add or remove a handler while the processor is running.
If an attempt is made to add a handler when one is currently registered.

member.name: E:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient.SendEventBatchFailedAsync
member.summary:
Invoked for any batch of events that failed to be published to the Event Hub, this handler must be provided before events may be enqueued. If this producer was not configured with and both set to 1, the handler will be invoked concurrently.
It is safe to attempt resending the events by calling or from within this handler. It is important to note that doing so will place them at the end of the buffer; the original order will not be maintained.
This handler will be awaited after failure to publish the batch; the publishing operation is not considered complete until the handler call returns. It is advised that no long-running operations be performed in the handler to avoid negatively impacting throughput.
It is not recommended to invoke or from this handler; doing so may result in a deadlock scenario if those calls are awaited.
member.remarks:
Should a transient failure occur during publishing, this handler will not be invoked immediately; it is only invoked after applying the retry policy and all eligible retries have been exhausted. Should publishing succeed during a retry attempt, this handler is not invoked.
Since applications do not have deterministic control over failed batches, it is recommended that the application set a generous number of retries and try timeout interval in the . Doing so will allow the a higher chance to recover from transient failures. This is especially important when ensuring the order of events is needed.
It is not necessary to explicitly unregister this handler; it will be automatically unregistered when or is invoked.
member.exception: If an attempt is made to remove a handler that doesn't match the current handler registered.
If an attempt is made to add or remove a handler while the processor is running.
If an attempt is made to add a handler when one is currently registered.

member.name: M:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The connection string to use for connecting to the Event Hubs namespace; it is expected that the Event Hub name and the shared key properties are contained in this connection string.
member.remarks:
If the connection string is copied from the Event Hubs namespace, it will likely not contain the name of the desired Event Hub, which is needed. In this case, the name can be added manually by adding ";EntityPath=[[ EVENT HUB NAME ]]" to the end of the connection string. For example, ";EntityPath=telemetry-hub".
If you have defined a shared access policy directly on the Event Hub itself, then copying the connection string from that Event Hub will result in a connection string that contains the name.
member.seealso: How to get an Event Hubs connection string

member.name: M:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClient.EnqueueEventAsync(Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.EventData,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Enqueues an into the buffer to be published to the Event Hub. If there is no capacity in the buffer when this method is invoked, it will wait for space to become available and ensure that the has been enqueued.
When this call returns, the has been accepted into the buffer, but it may not have been published yet. Publishing will take place at a nondeterministic point in the future as the buffer is processed.
member.param: The event to be enqueued into the buffer and, later, published.
An optional instance to signal the request to cancel the operation.
member.returns: The total number of events that are currently buffered and waiting to be published, across all partitions.
member.exception: Occurs when no handler is currently registered.
member.remarks: Upon the first attempt to enqueue an event, the and handlers can no longer be changed.

member.summary:
Enqueues a set of into the buffer to be published to the Event Hub. If there is insufficient capacity in the buffer when this method is invoked, it will wait for space to become available and ensure that all in the set have been enqueued.
When this call returns, the have been accepted into the buffer, but it may not have been published yet. Publishing will take place at a nondeterministic point in the future as the buffer is processed.

An optional instance to signal the request to cancel the operation.

member.exception: Occurs when no handler is currently registered.
member.remarks:
Should cancellation or an unexpected exception occur, it is possible for calls to this method to result in a partial failure where some, but not all, of the have enqueued. For scenarios where it is important to understand whether each individual event has been enqueued, it is recommended to call the see or overloads instead of this method.
Upon the first attempt to enqueue events, the and handlers can no longer be changed.

member.summary: Abandons all events in the buffer that are waiting to be published. Upon completion of this method, the buffer will be empty.
member.param: An optional instance to signal the request to cancel the operation.
member.remarks:
This method will modify class-level state and should be synchronized. It is assumed that callers hold responsibility for ensuring synchronization concerns; this method should be invoked after any primitives have been acquired.
Callers are also assumed to own responsibility for stopping all publishing and performing any necessary validation of client state before calling.

member.name: T:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClientOptions
member.summary: The set of options that can be specified when creating an to configure its behavior.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClientOptions.EnableIdempotentRetries
member.summary: Indicates whether or not events should be published using idempotent semantics for retries. If enabled, retries during publishing will attempt to avoid duplication with a minor cost to throughput. Duplicates are still possible but the chance of them occurring is much lower when idempotent retries are enabled.
member.value: By default, idempotent retries are disabled.
member.remarks: It is important to note that enabling idempotent retries does not guarantee exactly-once semantics. The existing Event Hubs at-least-once delivery contract still applies and event duplication is unlikely, but possible.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClientOptions.MaximumWaitTime
member.summary: The amount of time to wait for a batch to be built with events in the buffer before publishing a partially full batch.
member.value:
The default wait time is 1 second. For most scenarios, it is recommended to allow for at least 1 second in order to ensure consistent performance.
If null, batches will only be published when full unless is called.
member.exception: Occurs when the requested wait time is negative.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClientOptions.MaximumEventBufferLengthPerPartition
member.summary: The total number of events that can be buffered for publishing at a given time for a given partition. Once this capacity is reached, more events can enqueued by calling or , which will automatically wait for room to be available.
member.value: The default limit is 1500 queued events for each partition.
member.exception: Occurs when the requested count is not between 1 and 1 million (inclusive).

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClientOptions.MaximumConcurrentSends
member.summary: The total number of batches that may be sent concurrently, across all partitions. This limit takes precedence over the value specified in , ensuring this maximum is respected.
member.value: By default, this will be set to the number of processors available in the host environment.
member.remarks: When batches for the same partition are published concurrently, the ordering of events is not guaranteed. If the order events are published must be maintained, should not exceed 1.
member.exception: Occurs when the requested count is not between 1 and 100 (inclusive).

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClientOptions.MaximumConcurrentSendsPerPartition
member.summary: The number of batches that may be sent concurrently for a given partition. This option is superseded by the value specified for , ensuring that limit is respected.
member.value: By default, each partition will allow only one publishing operation to be active in order to ensure that events are published in the order that they were enqueued.
member.remarks: When batches for the same partition are published concurrently, the ordering of events is not guaranteed. If the order of events must be maintained, should not exceed 1.
member.exception: Occurs when the requested count is not between 1 and 100 (inclusive).

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClientOptions.Identifier
member.summary: A unique name used to identify the consumer. If null or empty, a GUID will be used as the identifier.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClientOptions.ConnectionOptions
member.summary: The options used for configuring the connection to the Event Hubs service.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubBufferedProducerClientOptions.RetryOptions
member.summary: The set of options to use for determining whether a failed operation should be retried and, if so, the amount of time to wait between retry attempts. These options also control the amount of time allowed for publishing events and other interactions with the Event Hubs service.

member.name: T:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubProducerClient
member.summary:
A client responsible for publishing to a specific Event Hub, grouped together in batches. Depending on the options specified when sending, events may be automatically assigned an available partition or may request a specific partition.
The publishes immediately, ensuring a deterministic outcome for each send operation, though requires that callers own the responsibility of building and managing batches.
In scenarios where it is not important to have events published immediately and where maximizing partition availability is not a requirement, it is recommended to consider using the , which takes responsibility for building and managing batches to reduce the complexity of doing so in application code.

listheader.description: Allowing partition assignment is recommended when:

item.description: The sending of events needs to be highly available.
The event data should be evenly distributed among all available partitions.

listheader.description: If no partition is specified, the following rules are used for automatically selecting one:

item.description: Distribute the events equally amongst all available partitions using a round-robin approach.
If a partition becomes unavailable, the Event Hubs service will automatically detect it and forward the message to another available partition.

remarks.para: The is safe to cache and use for the lifetime of an application, which is the best practice when the application publishes events regularly or semi-regularly. The producer is responsible for ensuring efficient network, CPU, and memory use. Calling either or as the application is shutting down will ensure that network resources and other unmanaged objects are properly cleaned up.

member.name: M:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubProducerClient.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The connection string to use for connecting to the Event Hubs namespace; it is expected that the Event Hub name and the shared key properties are contained in this connection string.
member.remarks:
If the connection string is copied from the Event Hubs namespace, it will likely not contain the name of the desired Event Hub, which is needed. In this case, the name can be added manually by adding ";EntityPath=[[ EVENT HUB NAME ]]" to the end of the connection string. For example, ";EntityPath=telemetry-hub".
If you have defined a shared access policy directly on the Event Hub itself, then copying the connection string from that Event Hub will result in a connection string that contains the name.
member.seealso: How to get an Event Hubs connection string

member.name: M:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubProducerClient.SendAsync(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.EventData},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Sends a set of events to the associated Event Hub as a single operation. To avoid the overhead associated with measuring and validating the size in the client, validation will be delegated to the Event Hubs service and is deferred until the operation is invoked. The call will fail if the size of the specified set of events exceeds the maximum allowable size of a single batch.
member.param: The set of event data to send.
An optional instance to signal the request to cancel the operation.
member.returns: A task to be resolved on when the operation has completed; if no exception is thrown when awaited, the Event Hubs service has acknowledged receipt and assumed responsibility for delivery of the set of events to its partition.
member.remarks: When published, the result is atomic; either all events that belong to the set were successful or all have failed. Partial success is not possible.
member.exception: Occurs when the set of events exceeds the maximum size allowed in a single batch, as determined by the Event Hubs service. The will be set to in this case.
Occurs when one of the events in the has a member in the collection that is an unsupported type for serialization. See the remarks for details.

member.name: M:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubProducerClient.CreateBatchAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary:
Creates a size-constraint batch to which may be added using a try-based pattern. If an event would exceed the maximum allowable size of the batch, the batch will not allow adding the event and signal that scenario using its return value.
Because events that would violate the size constraint cannot be added, publishing a batch will not trigger an exception when attempting to send the events to the Event Hubs service.
member.param: An optional instance to signal the request to cancel the operation.
member.returns: An with the default batch options.

member.param: The set of options to consider when creating this batch.

member.returns: An with the requested .

member.summary: The set of options to use for determining whether a failed operation should be retried and, if so, the amount of time to wait between retry attempts. These options also control the amount of time allowed for publishing events and other interactions with the Event Hubs service.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubProducerClientOptions.EnableIdempotentPartitions
member.summary: Indicates whether or not the producer should enable idempotent publishing to the Event Hub partitions. If enabled, the producer will only be able to publish directly to partitions; it will not be able to publish to the Event Hubs gateway for automatic partition routing nor using a partition key.
member.value: true if the producer should enable idempotent partition publishing; otherwise, false. Idempotent partitions are disabled by default.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.EventHubProducerClientOptions.PartitionOptions
member.summary:
The set of options that can be specified to influence publishing behavior specific to the configured Event Hub partition. These options are not necessary in the majority of scenarios and are intended for use with specialized scenarios, such as when recovering the state used for idempotent publishing.
It is highly recommended that these options only be specified if there is a proven need to do so; Incorrectly configuring these values may result in an instance that is unable to publish to the Event Hubs.
member.value: The default partition options are an empty set.
member.remarks: These options are ignored when publishing to the Event Hubs gateway for automatic routing or when using a partition key.

member.name: T:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.PartitionPublishingOptions
member.summary: The set of options that can be specified for an to influence its behavior when publishing directly to an Event Hub partition.
member.remarks: These options are ignored when publishing to the Event Hubs gateway for automatic routing or when using a partition key.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.PartitionPublishingOptions.ProducerGroupId
member.summary: The identifier of the producer group that this producer is associated with when publishing to the associated partition. Events will be published in the context of this group.
member.value: The identifier of the producer group to associate with the partition; if null, the Event Hubs service will control the value.
member.remarks: The producer group is only recognized and relevant when certain features of the producer are enabled. For example, it is used by idempotent publishing.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.PartitionPublishingOptions.OwnerLevel
member.summary:
The owner level indicates that a publishing is intended to be performed exclusively for events in the requested partition in the context of the associated producer group. To do so, publishing will attempt to assert ownership over the partition; in the case where more than one publisher in the producer group attempts to assert ownership for the same partition, the one having a larger value will "win".
When an owner level is specified, other exclusive publishers which have a lower owner level within the context of the same producer group will either not be allowed to be created or, if they already exist, will encounter an exception during the next attempted operation. Should there be multiple producers in the producer group with the same owner level, each of them will be able to publish to the partition.
Producers with no owner level or which belong to a different producer group are permitted to publish to the associated partition without restriction or awareness of other exclusive producers.
member.value: The relative priority to associate with an exclusive publisher; if null, the Event Hubs service will control the value.
member.remarks: The owner level is only recognized and relevant when certain features of the producer are enabled. For example, it is used by idempotent publishing. The default owner level is null.
member.exception: Occurs when the owner level is set and the is unable to publish to the requested Event Hub partition due to being denied ownership. In this case, the will be set to .

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.PartitionPublishingOptions.StartingSequenceNumber
member.summary: The starting number that should be used for the automatic sequencing of events for the associated partition, when published by this producer.

value.para: The starting sequence number to associate with the partition; if null, the Event Hubs service will control the value.
The sequence number will be in the range of 0 - (inclusive) and will increase as events are published. When more than events have been published, the sequence number will roll over to 0.
The default sequence number is null.

member.remarks: The starting sequence number is only recognized and relevant when certain features of the producer are enabled. For example, it is used by idempotent publishing.

member.name: T:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.SendEventOptions
member.summary: The set of options that can be specified to influence the way in which events are published to the Event Hubs service.

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.SendEventOptions.PartitionKey
member.summary:
Allows a hashing key to be provided for the batch of events, which instructs Event Hubs to map the key to an automatically-assigned partition.
The selection of a partition is stable for a given partition key. Should any other events be published using the same exact partition key, Event Hubs will assign the same partition to them.
The partition key should be specified when there is a need to group events together, but the partition to which they are assigned is unimportant. If ensuring that a batch of events is assigned a specific partition, it is recommended that the be assigned instead.
member.value:
A value that can be used to identify events that should be published to the same partition. If null, the events will either respect the specified or be automatically assigned to a partition.
The default partition key value is null.
member.remarks: If the is specified, then no may be set when sending.
member.seealso: Mapping events to partitions

member.name: P:Azure.Messaging.EventHubs.Producer.SendEventOptions.PartitionId
member.summary: If specified, events be published to this specific partition. If the identifier is not specified, Event Hubs will be responsible for assigning events automatically to an available partition.
member.value:
The identifier of the desired partition to assign for the events, if null, the events will be automatically assigned to a partition.
The default partition identifier value is null.
member.remarks:
If the is specified, then no may be set when sending.
Allowing automatic routing of partitions is recommended when:
The sending of events needs to be highly available.
The event data should be evenly distributed among all available partitions.
If no partition is specified, the following rules are used for automatically selecting one:
Distribute the events equally amongst all available partitions using a round-robin approach.
If a partition becomes unavailable, the Event Hubs service will automatically detect it and forward the message to another available partition.
member.seealso: Mapping events to partitions

member.name: T:Azure.Core.Argument
member.summary: Provides a consistent means for verifying arguments and other invariants for a given member.
member.remarks: This class extends the type, referenced as a partial class via shared source; the base partial class definition may be found in the "SharedSource" folder of this project.
member.summary: Argument validation.

remarks.para: This class should be shared via source using Azure.Core.props and contain only common argument validation. It is declared partial so that you can use the same familiar class name but extend it with project-specific validation. To extend the functionality of this class, just declare your own partial class with project-specific methods.
Be sure to document exceptions thrown by these methods on your public methods.

member.name: T:Azure.Core.Shared.MessagingClientDiagnostics
member.summary: Client Diagnostics support for messaging clients. Currently, this is only used for AMQP clients. HTTP libraries should use the ClientDiagnostics type instead.

member.name: M:Azure.Core.Shared.MessagingClientDiagnostics.CreateScope(System.String,Azure.Core.Pipeline.DiagnosticScope.ActivityKind,Azure.Core.Shared.MessagingDiagnosticOperation)
member.summary: Creates a diagnostic scope to be used for messaging operations. This method will add messaging-specific attributes to the scope taking into account the ActivitySource configuration. Links are not added here as in many instances links can only be added after the scope is already created.
member.param: The name to apply to the activity.
The kind to apply to the activity.
The type of messaging operation.
member.returns: The created diagnostic scope containing the common set of messaging attributes that are knowable upon creation.
